title: WiFi Hotspots & Internet Cafes
description: Lack of WiFi & availability of affordable computers, available to Africans impedes their progress, we must make it easier & affordable.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal basically asked for $25k to start researching cafe/sites that could host subsidised wifi. It is not to actually do the subsidizing nor does it how a plan for how this subsidizing would be done.
f6_assessments.q1: The experience presented is that the proposer has 43 yrs in business experience. That may qualify him, but what experience on the ground in Africa does he have? As with the other 9 projects submitted by the same proposer, this seems to be a relatively generic exposition of a problem, and a general plan to build some simple components to solve it but with out clear deliverables and an explanation of how this solution compares with other options or how it really is key to the challenge
f6_assessments.q2: Whilst there is a road map, the deliverables aren't very specific. It not delivering and wifi, just locating some sites where it could be done. How is this growing Africa?

f6_assessments.q0:
If you had followed the World Mobile operations in Africa you would know that the issue is not in hardware but in exuberant data costs and lack of connectivity in rural areas.

This proposal talks about WiFi hotspots and internet cafés. Yet those are not reflected in the budget.
f6_assessments.q1:
Budget line items are copypasted from your other proposals and don't match the plan outlined above.

You can't solve every issue by building a website and creating social media presence.
f6_assessments.q2:
You are asking $25,000 USD and one of your deliverables is "Prepare proposals for Fund 7". Seriously?

Please create a proposal that answers the set challenge: "How do we seed and grow Cardano in Africa?"

f6_assessments.q0: This problem truly addresses internet service problems and also computer illiteracy in the rural areas  in Africa. in this computer age of doing things, this proposal if addressed will help decrease the computer illiteracy in Africa and if continued, can gradually eradicate it from the continent slowly.
f6_assessments.q1: Looking at the other projects Carl Henry has brought about and implemented, I am 100% sure this proposal, if taken will go a long way to be successful.
f6_assessments.q2: Information provided will make it easy to follow the progress of this proposal and as well as audit and keep track of its implementation.

f6_assessments.q0: The benefit of an external company setting up Wifi in remote places to Africa and Cardano remains unclear.
f6_assessments.q1: While the plan is set up in a mostly detailed and correct manner, for several reasons, after some research the company does not seem up to the task. 1) The website and the social media does not match up to the self-acclaimed reputation and claimed size of the company (all media and social media coverage is selfmade, the wensite looks very unprofessional for someone who supposedly has been in the business for 23 years and the website discloses nothing about any staff member while there are apparently about 10 CH companies). Furthermore, taking a look into the UK business registry the company or versions of it was dissolved and re-found several times. The sheer amount of proposals from the proposer make it unlikely that he will be up to the task of finishing all of these. 2) Strike off requests from the company have been suspended or denied, which often means outstanding debt.
f6_assessments.q2: While milestones are set, some of the targets are defined very open. Furthermore, the fact that the company was already dissolved several times in the recent year make ot unlikely that the proposal can be audited. How can you audit a proposer who regularily dissolves his business?
f6_assessments.reply:
Dear vCA,
Only a personal opinion given: The assessor has decided they know the capabilities of the proposer based on a quick scan of social media and a misunderstanding about the status of the company, they have made a blanket judgement of all ten proposals based on incorrect judgements. There is no debt because the company has never traded, all assessments are copied and pasted on each of my proposals showing a general bias against all of my proposals.
Unconstructive assessment: The UK Companies are all in good order, this assessor does not understand UK company law, the companies have not been dissolved even once, Notices were served to dissolve the company one time, when I thought about discontinuing the project but I decided to continue and filed the necessary document to continue the company. This does not indicate a lack of ability to complete the proposal.
Regards,
Carl Henry

f6_assessments.q0:
Helping africans to get their hardware and connectivity in order to access the services Cardano has to offer is fundamental to help the whole continent.
Also, as mentioned by the proposer, training offered to newbies is going to be a key aspect for the project to succeed.
The language barrier has been thought so a part of the budget will be dedicated to translation
f6_assessments.q1:
The plan seems to provide equipment, connectivity and training to use a pc and internet, however there is no plan to necessarily involve a Cardano developer (e.g. Plutus Pioneer) to train new people to code as well for example.
Furthermore, it seems there is no plan to expand the number of users and it's not clear how the project would auto-sustain (funding from charity, users contributing themselves ect. ?)
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap is clear however it seems there is a poor correlation with the budget breakdown. For example, it's not stated when the translator will operate, and the budget seems not taking in account the cost of purchasing equipment.

solution: Subsidise WiFi access, make more recycled handsets & computers available, particularly in rural areas. Make online training available
experience: 43 Years in business, seen needs by the poor & developing first hand
